items.title: Elon Musk will settle $128 million Twitter execs lawsuit
items.summary: Elon Musk has agreed to settle with four top Twitter executives he fired after purchasing the company in 2022, after they sued the billionaire over more than $128 million in unpaid severance last year.  An update to the case filed in the US Northern District Court of California says that the parties — Twitter’s former […]

items.title: Sany Araby seeks PM's permission to launch second humanitarian mission to Gaza
items.summary: KUALA LUMPUR: Sumud Nusantara Malaysia is seeking permission from Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim to initiate a second humanitarian mission to deliver aid to Gaza, Palestine via Egypt by land, Sinar Harian reports. Read full story

Normally sitting up at its full $1,800 price, discounts are pretty rare on this model, as opposed to the few but more frequent savings that hit its counterparts in the brand’s e-transportation series. items.title: Google’s virtual try-on shopping tool expands to more countries, now lets you try on shoes
items.summary: To virtually try on a pair of shoes, users need to tap on any product listing on Google, select the "try it on" button and then add a full length photo themselves.

items.summary: An architect and three workers were among those who died at the building which was being renovated.

items.summary: Wednesday's attack comes days after a similar strike caused mass power cuts.

items.title: Need for flexible foreign policy that remains true to core values, says Tok Mat
items.summary: KUALA LUMPUR: There is a need for a foreign policy that has principles in holding on to core values and national interest and yet is flexible enough to adapt to shifting realities, says Datuk Seri Mohamad Hasan. Read full story

items.title: A Twitch streamer gave birth live, with Twitch’s CEO in the chat
items.summary: On Tuesday, Twitch streamer Fandy took a break from streaming games like World of Warcraft, Overwatch, and League of Legends, to broadcast herself giving birth. The eight-hour-long stream captured the livestreamer going into labor and eventually giving birth to her child inside a small inflatable pool in a living room, as thousands of viewers tuned […]

items.title: Ex-FBI chief Comey pleads not guilty to charges brought under pressure from Trump
items.summary: ALEXANDRIA, Virginia (Reuters) -Former FBI Director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Department against one of President Donald Trump's political enemies. Read full story

items.title: A survey of US parents: 90% say their kids aged 12 or younger watch TV, 68% say their kids use a tablet, and 61% use a smartphone; 8% of kids use an AI chatbot (Pew Research Center)
items.summary:
Pew Research Center:
A survey of US parents: 90% say their kids aged 12 or younger watch TV, 68% say their kids use a tablet, and 61% use a smartphone; 8% of kids use an AI chatbot  —  From YouTube to smartphones to tablets, tech is part of kids' lives.  AI chatbots are part of the mix now, too.

It only hit the market in June with a $200 price tag attached, which has been dropping lower and lower as the weeks go on, so far having gone down to $140 at the lowest back during July’s Prime Day event. You’ll also find several more indoor and outdoor smart lighting devices from the brand starting from $10.

Amazon currently has Lenovo’s latest 2025 Tab One Android tablet with folio case down at $99.99 shipped. This particular unit debuted earlier this year carrying a $160 price tag, and it’s now seeing a $60 discount. We saw this one drop to $110 last month, but today’s deal at Amazon shaves an additional $10 off its usual going rate to mark the best price we have tracked for it to date. What’s particularly worth noting here is that the Amazon listing includes a folio case for just $5 more than Lenovo’s current offer of $94.99 shipped (with promo code EXTRAFIVE) for just the tablet alone without the case. It spent most of 2025 keeping to its $100 full price, with discounts over the year (coming in more frequent waves in recent months) having taken costs down as low as $80 normally, with a one-time drop to the $60 low back at the end of August that lasted only a few hours. Aside from that short-term deal, you’re otherwise looking at the next-best rate of the year, saving you $20 and giving you a versatile means to jump-start vehicles, as well as personal devices.
